JUDGES: Giovanni Bonello;Ján Šikuta;Lech Garlicki;Mihai Poalelungi;Nebojša Vučinić;Nicolas Bratza
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant sued CARDINAL professors from ORG ( ORG ) before ORG ( PERSON ) alleging professional misconduct on their part and seeking protection of his personal rights . He submitted that the professors had deliberately made him fail his DATE of studies . They allegedly prohibited him from participation in lectures and the examinations . In this respect he claimed ORG MONEY in compensation from the professors and PLN MONEY from the University .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant submitted information concerning his financial situation . He maintained that he received a family pension in the amount of PLN CARDINAL . He further stressed that he was a student , that he did not work and that he had incurred huge debts on his bank account ( MONEY ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG asked the applicant to submit a copy of his bank statement and the contract for the purchase of his car . In reply , on DATE the applicant sent a letter to the court , claiming that his debts amounted to ORG . However , he could not ask the bank for a statement because the bank would have discovered his debts . He was also not able to submit the contract for the purchase of his car ( Renault Clio ) as it had been bought with his mother ’s money .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG refused to exempt the applicant from the payment of court fees . The court held that the applicant had failed to submit evidence i.e. his bank statement in support of his allegations that he had substantial debts . According to the court , the fact that the applicant owned a ORG Clio was an indication that his financial situation was sound . The court stressed that it was impossible to cover the costs of the car maintenance with the applicant ’s pension .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged an interlocutory appeal . He stressed that the court fee for lodging his claim exceeded ORG CARDINAL , which he was unable to pay . He further maintained that he did not own any real estate and that he rented his apartment under the rent - control scheme . Moreover , he was not even able to pay the reduced rent and he already owed ORG to the housing co - operative . He further claimed that the fact that he owned a car was of no relevance as he had bought it DATE when his financial situation had been better , given that he had had a part - time job at the time . He did not have a copy of the contract for the purchase of the car . However , he maintained that he had bought a new car and had paid ORG CARDINAL for it .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG again refused the applicant ’s request . The court stressed that the fact that the applicant owned a car worth ORG MONEY and at the same time his only income was a family pension of ORG CARDINAL indicated that his financial situation was good and that he must have had some hidden resources . Otherwise , he would not be able to support himself and to maintain his car . According to the court , the applicant was trying to conceal his real financial situation .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged an interlocutory appeal against this decision . He claimed that the court ’s refusal to exempt him amounted to a violation of his right of access to a court .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s interlocutory appeal . The court held that a person applying for legal aid should not take out a loan in a situation when he still had assets ( a car ) . In addition , the applicant had failed to provide a detailed statement about his financial situation .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ordered the applicant to pay ORG MONEY as a fee for lodging his statement of claim on pain of having his claim returned .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant again asked to be exempted from the court fees . He claimed that he was unable to pay that amount . He owed PLN CARDINAL to the bank and had no savings . In addition , his claim related to the protection of personal rights . As regards his car , he could not sell it since a different set of civil proceedings concerning it was pending . Lastly , he maintained that apart from the family pension - PLN CARDINAL - he did not have any other income . He had no possessions and the car was his only asset .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG refused the applicant ’s request . The court held that the applicant should have sold his car in order to obtain money for court fees .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant again lodged an interlocutory appeal against this decision . The applicant repeated his earlier arguments and referred to the right of access to a court .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG gave a decision and exempted the applicant from PERCENT of the court fees for lodging his statement of claim . The court found that the court fee in the amount of ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL constituted a limitation on the applicant ’s right of access to a court and that the amount had to be reduced . At the same time , it held that a court fee in the amount of MONEY could not be considered excessive for the applicant .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant again made an interlocutory appeal and submitted that ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL was too much and he was unable to pay it .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG refused to grant the applicant any further exemption from court fees . Upon the applicant ’s further appeal , ORG upheld the decision on DATE . The court held that the applicant had not submitted any new arguments which would have justified a further exemption from court fees .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ordered the applicant to pay a court fee of ORG MONEY for lodging his statement of claim on pain of having the claim returned .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged yet another motion for an exemption from court fees . He stated among other things that he had lost the right to a family pension .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG returned the statement of claim to the applicant as he had failed to pay the required court fee . On DATE ORG quashed the decision to return the statement of claim to the applicant . On DATE it dismissed the applicant ’s motion for an exemption . It held that there were no new circumstances which would argue in favour of allowing the applicant ’s request . The applicant appealed to ORG .

CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s interlocutory appeal . The court held that the applicant had already been exempted from the greater part of the fees due in his case ( PERCENT ) and that he only had to pay ORG MONEY . Furthermore , despite his allegedly bad financial situation , the applicant had been able to maintain a car . The court acknowledged that the car was the subject of enforcement proceedings . However , since the applicant had not been able over a DATE period to set aside the sum required for court fees , his application for an exemption had to be dismissed .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG returned the statement of claim to the applicant since he had failed to pay the required court fee . The applicant appealed .
CARDINAL . On DATE the court ordered the applicant to pay the court fee of PLN CARDINAL for lodging an interlocutory appeal . On DATE the applicant asked to be exempted from payment of this fee .
CARDINAL . On DATE the court asked the applicant to submit a detailed statement about his financial situation .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG exempted the applicant from the fee for lodging his interlocutory appeal .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s interlocutory appeal against the decision to return the statement of claim to him .
